addressleaf.section:
Copie of a letter to M
r
Secre
t
Walsingham
e 30 Ja
n
88.

Copie of a l
re
to M
r
Secre
t
Walsingham 30. Ja
n
88.

A
o
88. A
o
89 A
o
1588 and 1589

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589. sti: Rom
30 January To M
r
Secretary
Walsingham
It may please yo
r
H. I have heerw
t
sent
e copie of
that w
ch
I delivered
e
states g
n
rall,
uppon her
Ma
ties
Instructions: also their Answear, and my Replie againe,
Wherein I have used
M
r
Gilpins
assistance, by whose ad-
vise, as likewise by
M
r
Killigrewes
, I did alter divers
pointes, to the end they might have bin
e better drawen
on, to a good acceptation, at
e lest of some of them. But
I finde them very stiffe, Wheresoever
ei settle: especially
Barnevelt,
who, as I suspect, doth continew in his wonted
alienation, for any good conceat of her Ma
ties
proceedinges.
I have dealt w
t
him privatly and publickly, and I have
offered my extraordinarie travell for effecting sundrie
their demaundes. But it seemeth by his speeches, and
by
e cariage of himself, that he hath litle respect, to any
promise that we make. The Answear w
ch
I send
was of his owne penning, and savoureth alltogether of
his ordinarie phrase, w
ch
is somwhat imperious, violent
and bitter: w
ch
in making
e Replie, I thought behoo-
full not to leave untouched, though not so muche to the
quicke, as happely was needefull, in an answear for
her Ma
tie
. I hope aswell that as all
e rest will stand
w
t
yo
r
H. good liking, considering there is nothing sette
downe, to prejudice suche farther answear, as her Ma
tie
shall send hither. I am every day urged by
e
Councell,
and somwhat angerly sometimes, as if I had
co
m
ission sufficient, about reducing
e Cautionarie
garrisons to
e nomber by Contract: wherto I make
no other
resoluc
o
n
answear, but that it was her Hig
nes
resoluc
o
n, and so doth continewe, unles their owne
backwardnes, in according her petitions, shall occasion
e contrary. I can not use more inducements
unto them, for
e releasment of
Deventer,
and
e
restituc
o
n of those of
Leiden,
e
President Aisma
&
then I have done already. But I see
at almost the
very names of those persons are odious unto them: of
Deventer in speciall: whose very best frindes have al-
most given over, to solicite his deliverance. For they
fol.32v
finde a strong opinion conceaved of him, that being sette on
libertie, he will worke his revenge, by setting a foote
many sinister practises, ether in
England
or els where, to
the ruine of these Provinces. Moreover I have bin openly
answeared at
e Councell table, that since my c
o
ming hi-
ther, and her Ma
ties
last writing, he hath braved
e ma-
gistrats of
Utrecht,
w
t
so muche insolence, as they could
not digest it. They have lately charged him againe w
t
newe Articles, and restrined him from his former liber-
tie in prison. It is most mens talke, and I do partly
perceave it by
e humo
r
of his letters, that his owne vaine
glory hath done him very muche harme, and hath caused
him to advise his frindes to suche courses, as nether stand
w
t
their credit, nor his owne. Nevertheles for
at I know
it is her Hig
nes
pleasure, I doe not give over, to practise his
enlargement. This day I receaved a letter from him, re-
questing me to write once againe to
e
Count de Meurs
: w
ch
I have done to suche purpose, as he himself hath req
e
sted.
Likewise for
Saravia,
and
e rest of Leiden,
Frise
&
I can gett no other answear, then
at w
ch
is in writing.
As yet I can not lett yo
r
H. understand, howe well this
people shalbe able to continew their meanes of contribu-
tion. What assistance they will yeld, for
e protecting
of any place,
at shall be offered in
e
united
revolted
Provinces.
Who they are among
e Principals, that stand best affected
to her Ma
tie
Nether can I satisfie those other demandes.
W
ch
I receaved of yo
r
H. in a privat memoriall. It
will require some longer continuance and triall among
them, if I shall deliver my censure, not uppon
e con-
ceat of other men, but judicially of my self. I have
moved M
r
Gilpin, about
e meanes to take up mony for
her Ma
tie
uppon
e
Marchants adventurers
bandes, w
ch
he
thinkes may be done, in sundrie places of
Germany.
The last that I receaved from yo
r
H. was of
e 27 of De
c
W
t
a letter from her Ma
tie
to
Scheincke,
w
ch
I sent away pre-
sently, by a very convenient messenger, who is not yet re-
turned. I doe not certifie yo
r
H of
e particular
proceedinges of divers Provinces, because I knowe M
r
Gilpin
fol.33r
doth it, and can doe it more effectually. For their con-
sultac
o
ns, for
e most, are in Flemmishe, and likewise their
recordes, whiche are alwaies in his handling. Likewise
concerning
e horsbandes and footbandes, that should be sent
for
Portugall,
because I have nothing therein in particular
charge, I am
e bolder to referre yo
r
H. to my
L. G
n
ralls
letters, and
S
r
Edward Norris
relation, betaking yo
r
H.
to Gods preservation.
From
e Hage. Ja
n
30. 88.
Yo
r
H most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
It may please yo
r
H because I finde every day
that
e States General, and
e
states of Holland
and
Zeland
proceede in writing and proposing of
most maters, aswell heere, as to her Ma
tie
w
t
out
e privitie of
e Councell of state, I am to beseche
yo
r
H.
at whatsoever l
re
s, articles or proposals
shalbe made by
ortell,
or any other their Minister,
if they shall concerne any mater fitte to be imparted
unto me, it may please yo
r
H. to acquaint me
w
t
them, for my better correspondence w
t
her Ma
ties
resoluc
o
ns.
